prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my friend she’s still single due to having 5 babies by different fathers?
She finished her 5th divorce two years ago, and for these two years she keeps asking me questions that also insult me.

 “How did you get a man at 30 with kids? It’s because you’re so skinny.” 

“Do I have to stop eating like you? Haha haha”

“You has so many dates. Guys only want basic blondes who are girly.”

“Did you only talk about sex with them?!”

For two years I’ve brushed off the insults, and replied: “ You’re in a small town” or “focus on yourself , and someone special will come around”

Finally she asks for the billionth time “How did you get any dates at 30 with kids?!? You don’t even have a real job! Tell me the truth- why can’t I get anyone?”

I replied honestly and said: “ You have five kids with different dads and none of them pay child support. It’s going to be hard for someone to accept that when you openly are looking for a father figure.”

This launched her into an insult fury, and she hung up on me. 

For reference: I’m not skinny but I work out (healthy weight). I eat more than her, honestly, not starving. I’m girly about some things I guess. I have two kids by the same dad and we split custody 50/50. I work in the adult industry, but only need to put in 8-10 hours a week to make a way better than average income. She keeps insulting my work even though she tried to do it, as well. I also have a vanilla job and an MBA. 

I was tired of being hit low quality and untrue insults, so I replied with what I thought was the truth.

Now, all of our mutual friends are saying I have skinny privilege and such. I’m entitled and don’t understand what she’s going through. They said it was messed up to say that and I’m a shitty friend, and I get whatever I want. She’s not going through anything that major. She’s just dating and being a mom like I had to do. 

Now I’m stuck with my mouth shut, and I’m mad at everyone because I’m not privileged or entitled at all- I’ve worked very hard for anything and everything I have.  And side note- the girl keeps talking about her

AITA for saying that? Was there a better thing to say? 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. So, the situation is that the author's friend has been divorced five times, each time with different fathers, and now the friend is asking the author questions that come off as insulting. The author has been brushing them off but finally responds by pointing out the friend's situation with the five kids and no child support. The friend gets angry and hangs up. Now, mutual friends are saying the author was wrong and that they have "skinny privilege" and are entitled.

Hmm, the key here is whether the author's response was justified. The friend's comments were clearly mean and personal, attacking the author's weight, job, and dating life. The author tried to be supportive but eventually snapped. The response about the five kids and child support is a factual point, but is bringing that up appropriate?

On one hand, the author was defending themselves after being insulted repeatedly. They might feel justified in pointing out the reason why the friend is struggling to find a partner. However, bringing up the number of children and the absence of child support might be a sensitive topic. Even if it's true, it could be perceived as judgmental or hurtful, especially if the friend is already in a vulnerable place. 

The mutual friends think the author was wrong and used "privilege," but the author argues they've worked hard and aren't entitled. It's a bit of a gray area. The friend's behavior was definitely inappropriate, but the author's response might have crossed a line. Maybe there was a better way to address it without being so direct. But since the friend was attacking the author, the author might feel they had the right to respond. 

I'm leaning towards the author not being in the wrong because they were responding to ongoing insults and trying to give a truthful answer. However, maybe the delivery was harsh. But given the context of being insulted, the author's response was in self-defense. So, probably the answer is B (No), the author isn't in the wrong.
